audio_caption: The audio begins with a ringing sound. A male speaker then describes his experience in a 1970s programmer community where software was shared, portraying it as a good way of life, before stating that the community was later destroyed.

The clip begins with a male speaker recalling a negative experience with proprietary software, leading him to declare, "I refuse to live that life." He speaks about building an entirely new world of software for freedom. This is followed by the sound of a wind chime. The speaker then defines free software as software that gives users freedom, elaborating on freedoms such as running the program, studying it, and making changes. He emphasizes the freedom to help one's neighbor and community by sharing and improving the software. The clip concludes with the speaker starting a sentence, "You know, Linux…"

The audio clip begins with a male speaker reflecting on life's challenges to freedom. He emphasizes the need to "defend our freedom constantly" and value it to understand its importance and be ready to fight for it when threatened. As he concludes, a bicycle bell rings briefly. The speaker then refers to a specific time period: "In 1900..."

The clip opens with a single male speaker announcing his plan to develop a free software operating system in 1983, stating that "in order to run your computer, you need an operating system". He explains the problem of all existing systems being "proprietary, non-free," and the need for a free one to "live in freedom." As an operating system developer, he felt he had a chance, especially with help.

The audio begins with a male speaker explaining that "GNU/Linux" is the combination of the "GNU operating system" and a program called Linux, spoken in an informative tone. This is briefly interrupted by the sound of a ringing bell, before the speaker returns, identifying as a hacker since the 1960s and explaining that "to be a hacker means to do things in a spirit of playful cleverness" and to explore the limits. The speaker continues on to say that "you can be a hacker in all sorts of different media".

The clip begins with a male speaker saying "programming is just one of them...". His tone is conversational. He claims "pirates are people who attack ships" and, in contrast, "people who share software are good neighbors." He believes "free software" shows how globalization "can be a good thing." There is a gentle, intermittent ringing sound in the background. The speaker continues, noting that the "free software movement has been global since the 80s" and now spans "six continents." He contrasts "globalization of power" with the "globalization of voluntary cooperation." The speaker explains that "free software makes it hard to have global mega-corporations." He suggests it facilitates "a different kind of business, providing support and services to people in your area" because "free software" allows one to hire someone to make changes. Many small companies offer support in their areas of expertise, typically to "people in their region," "people who speak the same language" etc. Finally, the ringing sound reappears.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the implications of teaching children to use non-free software, claiming it trains them to be under the domination of software owners. He argues that this could lead to extra work or loss of freedom and money for the children as adults, directing society into a rut of non-free software.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing the "free software movement" and its inspiration from "scientific cooperation." He continues, noting that people are taking "the inspiration back to science," and asserts that the "spirit of scientific cooperation is endangered today" due to "corporate funding for research." He suggests that "government agencies and everybody ought to switch to free software" so users can control their computers, as proprietary software gives control to the owner instead. Then, the sound of a ringing telephone briefly dominates before the clip concludes.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker criticizing the naive myth of the patent system. He mentions developing something innovative, “the patent", and cautions that this isn't the case for software. He explains that a product that isn't trivially simple has different ideas combined, and that developers are in danger from software patents. He explains that a developer in a country that allows software to be patented "can be sued for the software he writes". He contrasts this to the system of copyright. He argues that "patents work very differently," and that a person could get sued "for writing and for using a program yourself."

The audio clip features a single male speaker expressing concern about Microsoft's patent applications, specifically mentioning ".net" and the company attempting to patent "important basic ideas". The speaker sounds serious and critical. There are no discernible background sounds or music.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Microsoft designing a new file format and applying for a patent on it. The speaker continues by mentioning that mega-corporations use patents to pressure others to cross-license, and software patents would not protect small developers from competition. The overall tone is informative and slightly critical of mega-corporations.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing a directive on software patents being considered in Europe. He says the text of the directive was written by the Business Software Alliance. The speaker says it was possible to know that because it was released in word format, they forgot to remove deleted portions of the text and other hidden information, which people were then able to look at, and see who really wrote it. The speaker says it was someone who works for the business software alliance.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing software patents, emphasizing how their absence in Europe benefits European developers as they can't be sued at home. He contrasts this with the US system, saying anyone worldwide can obtain US software patents and "attack us poor Americans."  He expresses a hope that the US will "wise up" and eliminate its harmful policy.  The clip concludes with the distinct ringing of bells.
